images.place: Hong Kong Garden, Las Vegas, Nevada

description:
This category is updated with the latest dishes added to this app.

**Characters**

[新](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E6%96%B0) means *new*, and [菜](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E8%8F%9C) is *dish* (or *vegetable* or *cuisine*), so 新菜 is *new dish*.

[Sichuan cuisine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sichuan_cuisine), one of the great [eight great cuisines of China](https://thewoksoflife.com/8-chinese-cuisines/), is the food of Sichuan provice (otherwise known in English as Szechuan). It's famous, or notorious, for its spiciness.

**Books**

The Food of Sichuan by Fuschia Dunlop is a compendium of Sichuan recipes and reminiscences. I also recommend her memoir.

**Characters**

The Chinese characters for Sichuan, [四川](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/四川), is *four rivers* ([四](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/四) is *four* and [川](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/川) is (and looks like) *river*). [菜](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/菜) is *vegetables* but also more generally type of *dish* or *cuisine*, so 四川菜 is *Sichuan cuisine*. But it's generally shortened to 川菜.

[Cantonese cuisine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cantonese_cuisine), one of the [eight great cuisines of China](https://thewoksoflife.com/8-chinese-cuisines/), is the food of Guangdong province.

**Characters**

Literally translated, Cantonese cuisine is 廣東菜, but 粵菜 is used.

images.place: New Asian BBQ, Las Vegas, Nevada

description:
[Dim sum](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dim_sum) are shared small dishes or steamer baskets of dumplings and other typically bite-sized foods.

**History**

Dim sum dishes originated from all over China and some even have Western influences, but dim sum as a Hong Kong and [Cantonese cuisine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cantonese_cuisine) (The English spelling is close to the Cantonese pronunciation *dím sām*) originated in the *yum cha* (drink tea) tradition of travelers stopping at teahouses for tea and snacks along the Silk Road (so dim sum was an early version of truck stop food).

Dim sum is known for being served in on carts in large restaurants, but these days it can be found in a variety of settings ranging from banquet-sized restaurants to cozier Hong Kong-style cafes (cha chaan teng) and ordered off a menu.

**Books**

[The Dim Sum Field Guide](https://www.penguinrandomhouse.com/books/533493/the-dim-sum-field-guide-by-carolyn-phillips/) by Carolyn Phillips is an illustrated overview of dim sum, Dim Sum: The Art of Chinese Tea Lunch by Ellen Leong Blonder is an illustrated collection of recipes and some background info. Dim Sum by Janice Wong and Ma Jian Jun presents recipes for traditional and new dim sum with a focus on the flour used in the wrappings. The [Nom Wah Cookbook](https://nomwah.com/cookbook/) by Wilson Tang features recipes from the Nom Wah Tea Parlor, a New York Chinatown institution, and profiles the immigrants and their descendants who've kept multi-generational businesses alive in Chinatown.

**Books for Kids**

[Dim Sum for Everyone!](https://gracelin.com/dim-sum-for-everyone/) by Grace Lin is an illustrated dim sum family outing. Dim Sum Time by Sin Siu Tang and Andrew Sun teaches Cantonese dim sum phrases.

**Characters**

The first character [點](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E9%BB%9E) means *a bit* or *a touch*, and the second character [心](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E5%BF%83) means *heart*, so [點心](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E9%BB%9E%E5%BF%83) can be translated as *a bit of heart* or *a touch of heart* or *touching the heart* (Grace Young in Breath of a Wok translates it as *a dot on the heart*). Anyway, the origin of the term is debated.

Other words where [心](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E5%BF%83) is the second character: *Be careful!* (小心 síu sām), *happy* (開心 hōi sām) and the vegetable *choy sum* (菜心 choi sām).

images.place: Lucky House Cafe, Las Vegas, Nevada

description:
[Hong Kong cuisine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hong_Kong_cuisine) is of course largely Chinese (in particular, Cantonese) but it has benefited from a continuing influx of other Asian and Western influences, resulting in some original takes, like Hong Kong-style French toast, Hong Kong-style iced lemon tea, Hong Kong-style egg tarts...

**Characters**

[港](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E6%B8%AF) the second character of *Hong Kong*, and [式](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E5%BC%8F) is style, so [港式](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E6%B8%AF%E5%BC%8F) is *Kong-style*.

images.place: Chef Kenny's Vegan Dim Sum, Las Vegas, Nevada

description:
With a long history of Buddhism and people just not able to afford meat, Chinese cuisine traditionally excels in flavorful and textured vegetable dishes and also “mock” meats made from tofu and wheat gluten (yes, gluten).

**Characters**

[素](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E7%B4%A0) is typically used in conjunction with a term to mean *vegetarian*, e.g. [素菜](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E7%B4%A0%E8%8F%9C) (sou choi) is *vegetarian dish*, [素餐](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E7%B4%A0%E9%A4%90) is *vegetarian meal*, [素食](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E7%B4%A0%E9%A3%9F) is *vegetarian food*.

[素]((https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E7%B4%A0)) also means *simple*, *plain*, or *clear*, so [素月](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E7%B4%A0%E6%9C%88) is a bright and clear moon, [素顏](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E7%B4%A0%E9%A1%8F) is *face without makeup*, and [素數](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E7%B4%A0%E6%95%B8) is *prime number*.

images.place: New Asian BBQ, Las Vegas, Nevada

description:
**Characters**

[海鮮](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E6%B5%B7%E9%AE%AE) means *seafood* ([海](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E6%B5%B7) is *ocean* and [鮮](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E9%AE%AE) is *fresh*, so *seafood* is literally *ocean fresh*).
